While the cult of Osiris was one of the most widespread and long-lived religious cults in ancient Egypt, there were some controversies and conflicts that arose within the cult over time. Here are some examples:

1. Conflicts over the role of Osiris: While Osiris was widely revered as the god of the afterlife, there were some disputes over his role relative to other gods. For example, during the reign of the pharaoh Akhenaten, who promoted the cult of the sun god Aten, there was a de-emphasis on the cult of Osiris. Some priests may have opposed the new cult, which led to a decline in the popularity of the Osirian myth during this period.

2. Intra-cult rivalries: Within the cult of Osiris itself, there were sometimes rivalries between different priesthoods or institutions. For example, there was a long-standing rivalry between the priesthoods of Memphis and Abydos, which both claimed to have the true head of Osiris. Similar rivalries existed between other regional centers of the Osirian cult as well.

3. Adaptation to changing beliefs: As Egyptian religion evolved over time, there were also some adjustments made to the Osirian myth and the rituals associated with it. For example, during the New Kingdom period, the god Amun became increasingly important and was sometimes merged with Osiris in religious texts and art. Priests may have argued over how to integrate these new beliefs with the existing Osirian cult.

4. Challenges from foreign religions: Finally, as Egypt encountered new cultures and religions from outside its borders, there were sometimes conflicts between the Osirian cult and these foreign beliefs. For example, during the Greco-Roman period, the cult of Isis and Osiris was challenged by the spread of Christianity in Egypt.

Overall, while the cult of Osiris was a dominant force in Egyptian religion for thousands of years, there were some disputes and conflicts that arose over time. These were often related to changes in Egyptian society and culture or the influence of foreign beliefs.
